messageBody:
y153446 wrote:

> Organizations that do *not* attempt testing these methods: How do
> they report their code coverage? For instance, do they "back-out"
> the
> amount of code represented by getters/setters and then report the
> percentage of remaining code covered? Or - do they lower the goal to
> something considerably less than 100%?

My strategies/ideas are different depending on which end of the
greenfield-to-legacy spectrum we're on.

The closer to greenfield (= almost all code is test-driven) we are, the
less important code coverage is as an primary measure of codebase
health. We recommend measuring the marginal cost of each new feature
instead. If we keep that low/steady in spite of arbitrarily low code
coverage, we don't sweat it. If a client sweats it in spite of
low/steady marginal cost of each new feature, I start looking for my
next client. Life's too short.

The closer to legacy (= almost no code is test-driven) we are, the more
I understand code coverage goals. I respect them more /only until/ we
get the marginal cost of adding features down to something reasonable
(at least mildly projectable). In that case, seeing a steady increase in
code coverage matters more than the speed of approaching an arbitrary
standard.

> Is anyone actually striving for near-100% code coverage?

No. I strive for low defect rates and consistent/projectable and low
marginal cost of new features. My clients appear to appreciate this.
